Kathleen_Edwards:
{{short description|Canadian singer-songwriter and musician|bot=PearBOT 5}} {{BLP sources|date=April 2021}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist| | name = Kathleen Edwards | image = Kathleen Edwards at the Black Sheep Inn.jpg | caption = Edwards at Wakefield, Quebec's Black Sheep Inn, September 1, 2011 | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1978|07|11}} | birth_place = [[Ottawa]], Ontario, Canada | origin = | instrument = {{hlist|Guitar|violin|vocals|bass guitar}} | genre = {{hlist|[[Alternative country]]|[[Folk music|folk]]}} | occupation = {{hlist|Musician|songwriter}} | years_active = 1999–present | label = Zoë, [[MapleMusic Recordings]], [[Rounder Records|Rounder]], [[Dualtone Records|Dualtone]] | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|kathleenedwards.com}} | current_members = | past_members = }} '''Kathleen Margaret Edwards'''{{cite web|url=https://www.ascap.com/repertory#/ace/search/workID/310686569 |title=AWAY |website=ASCAP |publisher=American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers |access-date=March 13, 2023}} (born July 11, 1978[http://www.kathleenedwards.org/bio.html] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060902215803/http://www.kathleenedwards.org/bio.html|date=September 2, 2006}}) is a Canadian singer-songwriter and musician. Her 2002 debut album, ''[[Failer]]'', contained the singles "Six O'Clock News" and "Hockey Skates".{{cite web |last=Whibbs |first=Chris |url=http://exclaim.ca/articles/multiarticlesub.aspx?csid1=121&csid2=778&fid1=31028 |title=Kathleen Edwards Method Acting |publisher=Exclaim.ca |date=April 26, 2008 |access-date=August 14, 2015 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090303062101/http://exclaim.ca/articles/multiarticlesub.aspx?csid1=121&csid2=778&fid1=31028 |archive-date=March 3, 2009 }} Her next two albums – ''[[Back to Me (Kathleen Edwards album)|Back to Me]]'' and ''[[Asking for Flowers]]'' – both made the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] list and reached the top 10 of Billboard's [[Top Heatseekers]] chart. In 2012, Edwards' fourth studio album, ''[[Voyageur (Kathleen Edwards album)|Voyageur]]'', became Edwards' first album to crack the top 100 and top 40 in the U.S., peaking at #39 on the U.S. [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and #2 in Canada. In 2012, Edwards' song "A Soft Place To Land" won the [[SOCAN Songwriting Prize]], an annual competition that honours the best song written and released by 'emerging' songwriters over the past year, as voted by the public.{{cite web|url=http://www.socansongwritingprize.ca/past-nominees-and-winners/|title=Past Nominees and Winners|website=SOCAN Songwriting Prize|access-date=January 19, 2019|archive-date=June 6, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170606114756/http://www.socansongwritingprize.ca/past-nominees-and-winners/|url-status=dead}} Her musical sound has been compared to [[Suzanne Vega]] meets [[Neil Young]].{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/reviews/album-kathleen-edwards-voyageur-rounder-6285364.html|title=Album: Kathleen Edwards, Voyageur (Rounder)|date=January 6, 2012|website=The Independent|access-date=January 19, 2019}} == Early life == Edwards, the daughter of a diplomat,(March 4, 2008). "[http://www.canada.com/ottawacitizen/news/arts/story.html?id=ae110b63-0c61-4f5c-bcc5-91af2758062c Kathleen Edwards gets politically charged] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130728190533/http://www.canada.com/ottawacitizen/news/arts/story.html?id=ae110b63-0c61-4f5c-bcc5-91af2758062c |date=July 28, 2013 }}", ''[[Ottawa Citizen]]''. Retrieved October 23, 2011. spent portions of her youth in KoreaLangness, David (March 1, 2008). "[http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2008/03/kathleen-edwards-a-songwriters-progress.html Kathleen Edwards: A Songwriter's Progress] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160107082754/http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2008/03/kathleen-edwards-a-songwriters-progress.html |date=January 7, 2016 }}", ''[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]''. Retrieved October 24, 2011. and Switzerland. Her father is Leonard Edwards, former Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs. At age 5, Edwards began classical violin studies that continued for the next 12 years.Deziel, Shanda (February 17, 2003). "[http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=M1ARTM0012445 Alt-country's New "It" Girl: Kathleen Edwards] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070817071308/http://thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=M1ARTM0012445 |date=August 17, 2007 }}", ''[[The Canadian Encyclopedia]]''. Retrieved October 24, 2011. As a teenager she lived overseas, where she spent much of her time listening to her brother's records of [[Neil Young]] and [[Bob Dylan]].Loftus, Johnny. "[http://www.allmusic.com/artist/kathleen-edwards-p527243/biography Kathleen Edwards: Biography]", [[Allmusic]]. Retrieved October 24, 2011. Her brother also bought her her first record, a [[Tom Petty]] album. After high school she decided not to attend post-secondary education, instead opting to play local clubs to pay the bills. ==Music career== In 1999, Edwards recorded a six-song EP entitled ''Building 55'' and pressed 500 copies. By the fall of 2000, she was on tour across Canada managing her own gigs. In 2001, she wrote seven of the ten songs for her 2002 debut release ''Failer''. Edwards played at [[SXSW]] in 2002 and was signed to Rounder Records and MapleMusic shortly after. ''Failer'' was released in Canada in the fall of 2002 on [[MapleMusic Recordings]].[http://www.cbcmusic.ca/posts/17548/cohen-gould-buffy-25-best-canadian-debut-albums "25 best Canadian debut albums ever"]. ''CBC Music'', June 16, 2017. In January 2003 ''Failer'' was released by [[Rounder Records]] in the US and internationally. ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' declared her one of year's most promising new acts and ''[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]]'' said that ''Failer''{{'s}} songs possessed "an indefinable pull that makes you love the characters they describe, no matter how fucked up they are." ''[[The New York Times]]'' praised Edwards as a writer whose songs can "pare situations down to a few dozen words while they push country-rock towards its primal impulses of thump and twang." She made her television network debut on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' where she performed "Six O'Clock News." In 2005, Edwards released ''[[Back to Me (Kathleen Edwards album)|Back to Me]]'', which also garnered considerable critical acclaim, and led to the release of the singles "Back to Me" and "In State". The track "Summerlong" was also featured on the soundtrack of the movie ''[[Elizabethtown (film)|Elizabethtown]]'' starring [[Orlando Bloom]] and [[Kirsten Dunst]]. [[Image:Kathleen Edwards at NXNE 2007.JPG|upright=0.66|thumb|left|Edwards performing at the 2007 NXNE festival]] In 2008, Edwards released her third studio album, ''[[Asking for Flowers]]''. It was described by the ''[[San Francisco Bay Guardian]]'' as "her finest album to date",{{Cite web |url=http://www.sfbg.com/entry.php?entry_id=6365&catid=107&volume_id=317&issue_id=378&volume_num=42&issue_num=33 |title=San Francisco Bay Guardian : Article : Flowers for Kathleen Edwards |access-date=June 12, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090302164414/http://www.sfbg.com/entry.php?entry_id=6365&catid=107&volume_id=317&issue_id=378&volume_num=42&issue_num=33 |archive-date=March 2, 2009 |url-status=dead }} and was a shortlisted nominee for the [[2008 Polaris Music Prize]].{{cite web |title=2008 – Winners and Nominees |url=http://www.polarismusicprize.ca/2008/ |publisher=Polaris Music Prize |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090813214249/http://www.polarismusicprize.ca/2008/ |archive-date=August 13, 2009 |access-date=December 9, 2009 |url-status=dead }} In contrast with 2005's ''Back to Me'', on which Edwards relied on her working band, ''Asking for Flowers'' predominantly features session musicians. In fall 2010, Edwards began working on her fourth studio album in Wisconsin. ''[[Voyageur (Kathleen Edwards album)|Voyageur]]'' was released in January 2012. It includes the single "Change the Sheets," and was co-produced by [[Justin Vernon]] of [[Bon Iver]].{{cite web | url=http://exclaim.ca/News/kathleen_edwards_unveils_voyageur | title=Kathleen Edwards Unveils 'Voyageur' | access-date=December 15, 2011}} She appeared on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' on January 17, 2012, singing "Change the Sheets" from her new album ''Voyageur''. In November 2019, Edwards released "It's Christmastime (Let's Just Survive)", her first new single since ''Voyageur'', on the [[Dualtone Records]] compilation album ''A Dualtone Christmas''.Brock Thiessen, [https://exclaim.ca/music/article/kathleen_edwards_emerges_with_new_christmas_song "Kathleen Edwards Emerges with Her First New Song Since 2012"]. ''[[Exclaim!]]'', November 6, 2019. In May 2020, Edwards released the single "Options Open" and announced ''Total Freedom'', her first new album in eight years. The album was released on August 14, 2020.{{Cite web|title=Kathleen Edwards On Taking A Break From Music And Finding 'Total Freedom'|url=https://www.npr.org/2020/08/08/900335002/kathleen-edwards-on-taking-a-break-from-music-and-finding-total-freedom|access-date=August 14, 2020|website=NPR.org|language=en}} ==Musical collaborations== In 2005, Edwards lent her vocals to the duet "The Plan", recorded with [[Matt Mays and El Torpedo]] for their self-titled album.[{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r741621|pure_url=yes}} allmusic ((( Matt Mays + El Torpedo > Overview )))] In 2006, she was nominated for [[Juno Awards]] for Songwriter of the Year and Adult Alternative Album of the Year for ''Back to Me''.[http://www.kathleenedwards.org/news.html kathleenedwards.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060902215833/http://www.kathleenedwards.org/news.html |date=September 2, 2006 }} In 2007, Edwards worked with [[John Doe (musician)|John Doe]], of the punk rock band [[X (U.S. band)|X]], on his solo album ''A Year in the Wilderness''. She sings on three tracks.[http://www.yeproc.com/artist_info.php?artistId=9863] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080105061142/http://www.yeproc.com/artist_info.php?artistId=9863|date=January 5, 2008}} In 2008 Edwards sang backup vocals on [[Bryan Adams]]' album ''[[11 (Bryan Adams album)|11]]'', and supported one of his tours. In 2009, she joined Adams on stage to sing one of Adams' songs, "Walk on By".{{cite web|url=http://radio3.cbc.ca/blogs/2009/03/Watch-Kathleen-Edwards-Juno-Performance-with-Bryan-Adams|title=Watch Kathleen Edwards Juno Performance with Bryan Adams|last=Paolozzi|first=John|date=March 30, 2009|work=CBC Radio 3|access-date=May 4, 2009}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In 2011 Edwards contributed vocals on [[Arkells]]' song "Agent Zero", off their second album ''[[Michigan Left (album)|Michigan Left]]''. "Soft Place to Land", one of two songs on Edwards' ''Voyageur'' album co-written with [[The Long Winters]] frontman [[John Roderick (musician)|John Roderick]], won the 2012 [[Society of Composers, Authors and Music Publishers of Canada|SOCAN]] [[SOCAN Songwriting Prize|Echo Songwriting Prize]].{{cite news | url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/music/kathleen-edwards-john-roderick-win-echo-music-prize/article4624562/ | title=Kathleen Edwards, John Roderick | publisher=The Globe and Mail | date=October 19, 2012 | access-date=December 20, 2012 | author=Wheeler, Brad}} She co-wrote the song "Good Woman", from [[Maren Morris]]'s 2019 album ''[[Girl (Maren Morris album)|Girl]]''.Jonathan Bernstein, [https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/kathleen-edwards-comeback-new-album-total-freedom-1001469/ "Kathleen Edwards Left Behind Roots-Music Stardom to Sell Coffee. Now She’s Back"]. ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', May 19, 2020. {{Clear}} ==Personal life== In 2004, Edwards married guitarist and collaborator [[Colin Cripps]]. They divorced in 2011. Edwards was later in a relationship with [[Justin Vernon]], Wisconsin-born singer/songwriter and front-man of the band [[Bon Iver]].{{cite web|url=http://blogs.dallasobserver.com/dc9/2011/09/kathleen_edwards_justin_vernon.php|title=Kathleen Edwards: "Justin [Vernon] Helped Me Construct Something That's a 180 For Me." | Dallas Observer|last=Dearmore|first=Kelly|date=September 12, 2011|publisher=Blogs.dallasobserver.com|access-date=August 14, 2015|archive-date=November 18, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111118021941/http://blogs.dallasobserver.com/dc9/2011/09/kathleen_edwards_justin_vernon.php|url-status=dead}} Edwards and Vernon separated in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://host.madison.com/entertainment/music/kathleen-edwards-gets-personal-on-new-album/article_cc50ec29-e779-5bc5-a789-2d33215ce23c.html|title=Kathleen Edwards gets personal on new album|author=Downing, Andy|date=September 25, 2012|publisher=77 Square|access-date=December 20, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://host.madison.com/entertainment/music/reviews/kathleen-edwards-gives-madison-its-money-s-worth-in-fearless/article_db8d4346-0989-11e2-8b53-0019bb2963f4.html|title=Kathleen Edwards gives Madison its money's worth in fearless show : Arts-madisondotcom|date=September 28, 2012|publisher=Host.madison.com|access-date=August 14, 2015}} In 2020, Edwards married property developer Sean McAdam.{{Cite web |last=Phillips |first=Caroline |date=May 5, 2021 |title=Acclaimed musician Kathleen Edwards set to premiere new music video Thursday for Shepherds of Good Hope |url=https://obj.ca/acclaimed-musician-kathleen-edwards-set-to-premiere-new-music-video-thursday-for-shepherds-of-good-hope/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230206091646/https://obj.ca/acclaimed-musician-kathleen-edwards-set-to-premiere-new-music-video-thursday-for-shepherds-of-good-hope/ |archive-date=2023-02-06 |access-date=2024-03-31 |website=Ottawa Business Journal}} The couple now make their home in St. Petersburg, Florida.{{Cite web |last=DeYoung |first=Bill |date=2022-11-19 |title=Kathleen Edwards: The Last Waltz and a new hometown |url=https://stpetecatalyst.com/kathleen-edwards-the-last-waltz-and-a-new-hometown/ |access-date=2024-03-31 |website=St Pete Catalyst |language=en-US}} Edwards stepped back from the music scene in 2014, launching a coffee house in [[Stittsville]] called Quitters along with Rick Tremblay (who was her manager when she worked in a downtown Starbucks in the 1990s).{{cite web|url=https://ottawacitizen.com/entertainment/local-arts/no-quitter-kathleen-edwards-finds-a-new-path-in-stittsville-coffee-shop|title=No quitter: Kathleen Edwards finds a new path in Stittsville coffee shop|website=Ottawa Citizen|access-date=December 31, 2015|ref=quitters}} She insisted that she is not leaving music but just taking a break, and that the name Quitters is "kind of tongue-in-cheek". Quitters closed on March 6, 2022 after Edwards sold the business, so that she could return to her music career.{{cite news |url=https://ottawacitizen.com/entertainment/kathleen-edwards-quits-quitters |title=Kathleen Edwards quits Quitters |last=Saxberg |first=Lynn |date=February 25, 2022 |work=Ottawa Citizen |access-date=March 6, 2022}} As of 2018, Edwards continued to perform sporadically, including a number of new songs.[https://kawarthanow.com/2019/06/26/kathleen-edwards-and-matt-mays-to-headline-final-day-of-peterborough-folk-festival/ "Kathleen Edwards and Matt Mays to headline final day of Peterborough Folk Festival"]. ''Kawartha Now'', June 26, 2019. In August 2019, following the suicide of American singer-songwriter [[Neal Casal]], Edwards opened up on Twitter about the struggle with depression that led her to take time away from her music career.Corey Atad, [https://etcanada.com/news/496628/canadian-singer-kathleen-edwards-opens-up-about-mental-health-struggles-following-death-of-neal-casal/ "Canadian Singer Kathleen Edwards Opens Up About Mental Health Struggles Following Death Of Neal Casal"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191115191931/https://etcanada.com/news/496628/canadian-singer-kathleen-edwards-opens-up-about-mental-health-struggles-following-death-of-neal-casal/ |date=November 15, 2019 }}.
